questions.Q: A bomb at rest explodes into three fragments of equal masses. Two fragments fly off at right angles to each other with equal of speeds $$5\,\text{m/s}$$. The speed of the third fragment is:
questions.E: By conservation of momentum: $$\vec 0=\vec p_1+\vec p_2+\vec p_3=m\vec v_1+m\vec v_2+m\vec v_3$$ where  $$|\vec v_1|=|\vec v_2|=v$$. Thus, $$\vec 0=\vec v_1+\vec v_2+\vec v_3$$. From the graph, it follows that $$v_3=\sqrt{v_1^2+v_2^2}=\sqrt{v^2+v^2}=\sqrt{2}v=5\sqrt{2}\,\text{m/s}$$

questions.Q: A bomb at rest explodes into three fragments of equal masses. Two fragments fly off at right angles to each other with speeds $$5\,\text{m/s}$$ and $$7\,\text{m/s} $$ respectively. The speed of the third fragment is:
questions.E: By conservation of momentum: $$\vec 0=\vec p_1+\vec p_2+\vec p_3=m\vec v_1+m\vec v_2+m\vec v_3$$. Thus, $$\vec 0=\vec v_1+\vec v_2+\vec v_3$$. From the graph, it follows that $$v_3=\sqrt{v_1^2+v_2^2}=\sqrt{5^2+7^2}=\sqrt{(5\,\text{m/s})^2+(7\,\text{m/s})^2}=\sqrt{74}\,\text{m/s}$$

questions.Q: A bomb of mass $$4m$$ at rest explodes into two fragments of masses $$m$$ and $$3m$$. The fragments fly off in opposite direction with velocities $$\vec v_1$$ and $$\vec v_2$$ respectively. If $$m=1\,\text{kg}$$, the ratio $$\frac{v_1}{v_2}$$ is:
questions.E: By conservation of momentum: $$\vec 0=\vec p_1+\vec p_2=m\vec v_1+3m\vec v_2$$. Thus, $$\vec v_1=-3\vec v_2$$. Thus, $$\frac{v_1}{v_2}=3$$

questions.Q: Two balls of masses $$m$$ and $$2m$$ collide elastically as shown in the figure. If $$m=0.5\,\text{kg}$$, $$|\vec v_1|=0.5\,\text{m/s}$$ and $$|\vec v'_2|=\frac{1}{3}\,\text{m/s}$$, the magnitude of $$\vec v'_1$$ is:
questions.E: By conservation of momentum: $$m\vec v_1=m\vec v'_1+2m\vec v'_2 \Leftrightarrow \vec v_1=\vec v'_1+2\vec v'_2$$. Plugging values for the velocities in this expression we have: $$0.5\vec i=\vec v'_1+2(\frac{1}{3})\vec i$$, i.e., $$\vec v'_1=-\frac{1}{6}\vec i$$. Hence $$|\vec v'_1|=\frac{1}{6}\,\text{m/s}$$

questions.Q: Two balls of masses $$m$$ and $$9m$$ collide elastically as shown in the figure. If $$m=0.5\,\text{kg}$$, $$|\vec v_1|=1.0\,\text{m/s}$$ and $$|\vec v'_2|=0.2\,\text{m/s}$$, the magnitude of $$\vec v'_1$$ is:
questions.E: By conservation of momentum: $$m\vec v_1=m\vec v'_1+9m\vec v'_2 \Leftrightarrow \vec v_1=\vec v'_1+9\vec v'_2$$. Plugging values for the velocities in this expression we have: $$(1)\vec i=\vec v'_1+(9)(0.2)\vec i$$. Hence $$\vec v'_1=-0.8\vec i\,\text{m/s}$$ and therefore $$|\vec v'_1|=0.8 \,\text{m/s}$$

questions.Q: A wagon of mass $$3m$$ and velocity $$\vec v_1=2\vec i \,\text{m/s}$$ collides elastically with a wagon of mass $$m$$ intitially at rest shown in the figure. If $$m=2\,\text{kg}$$ and $$|\vec v'_2|=3.0\,\text{m/s}$$, the magnitude of $$\vec v'_1$$ is:
questions.E: By conservation of momentum: $$3m\vec v_1=3m\vec v'_1+m\vec v'_2 \Leftrightarrow 3\vec v_1=3\vec v'_1+\vec v'_2$$. Plugging values for the velocities: $$(3)(2)\vec i=(3)\vec v'_1+(3)\vec i$$, i.e., $$\vec v'_1=1\vec i$$. Hence $$|\vec v'_1|=1\,\text{m/s}$$

questions.Q: Two wagons of masses $$3m$$ and $$m$$ and velocities $$\vec v_1=2.0\,\vec i\,\text{m/s}$$ and $$\vec v_2=-1.0\,\vec i\,\text{m/s}$$ respectively move in oppo site direction and collides elastically as shown in the figure. If $$m=2\,\text{kg}$$ and $$\vec v'_1=-0.5\,\vec i \,\text{m/s}$$, the vector $$\vec v'_2$$ is:
questions.E: By conservation of momentum: $$3m\vec v_1+m\vec v_2=3m\vec v'_1+m\vec v'_2 \Leftrightarrow 3\vec v_1+\vec v_2=3\vec v'_1+\vec v'_2 $$. Plugging values for the velocities: $$(3)(2.0)\,\vec i+(-1)\,\vec i=(3)(0.5)\,\vec i+\vec v'_2$$. From this expression we have: $$\vec v'_2=3.5\,\vec i \,\text{m/s}$$

questions.Q: A wagon of mass $$3m$$ and velocity $$\vec v_1=10.0\,\vec i\,\text{m/s}$$ collides inelastically with a wagon of mass $$m$$ initially at rest. As a result, the two wagons stick together and move with speed $$\vec V$$. If $$m=10\,\text{kg}$$ the vector $$\vec V$$ is:
questions.E: By conservation of momentum: $$3m\vec v_1=4m\vec V \Leftrightarrow 3\vec v_1=4\vec V$$. From this equation: $$\vec V=\frac{3}{4}\vec v_1$$. Plugging values for the velocities: $$\vec V=\frac{3}{4}(10)\vec i=7.5\,\vec i \,\text{m/s}$$.
